name: Path

aliases.name: Path
aliases.comment: A path is a list of [`SubPath`](#subpath)s.

values.name: element
values.comment: Construct an svg path element from a `Path` with the given attributes

values.name: fromLowLevel
values.comment: Converting a svg-path-lowlevel subpath into a one-true-path subpath. Used in parsing

values.name: parse
values.comment:
Parse a path string into a `Path`

    import SubPath exposing (SubPath, subpath)
    import LowLevel.Command exposing (moveTo, lineTo)

    expected : SubPath
    expected =
        subpath (moveTo (0,0)) [ lineTo [ (42, 73) ] ]

    parse "M0,0 l42,73"
        --> Ok [expected]


Only accepts valid complete subpaths (a sequences of a move followed by zero or more draws). Relative instructions are converted to absolute ones. Short-hand curve extensions are converted to explicit curve instructions.

The parser uses [`elm-tools/parser`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-tools/parser/2.0.1/).
The error type is [`Parser.Error`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-tools/parser/2.0.1/Parser#Error).

values.name: toLowLevel
values.comment: Convert a path to a svg-path-lowlevel list of subpaths

values.name: toString
values.comment:
Turn a `Path` into a `String`. The result is ready to be used with the `d` attribute.


    myPath : SubPath
    myPath =
        subpath (moveTo (0,0)) [ lineTo [ (42, 73) ] ]


    Path.toString [ myPath ]
        --> "M0,0 L42,73"

    -- forms a cycle (almost isomorphism) with parse
    arc : String
    arc = "M80,230 A45,45 90 0 1 125,275"

    arc
        |> parse
        |> Result.map Path.toString
        --> Ok arc

name: Curve

values.name: basis
values.comment: Basis interpolation (also known as B-spline)

values.name: basisClosed
values.comment: Closed Basis interpolation (also known as B-spline)

values.name: basisOpen
bundle
cardinal
cardinalClosed
cardinalOpen
catmullRom
catmullRomClosed
catmullRomOpen
cubicBezier
values.comment: Shorthand to draw a sequence of cubic bezier segments
values.type: Vector2.Vec2 Float -> List ( Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float ) -> SubPath.SubPath

values.name: linear
values.comment: Draw straight lines between the data points.

values.name: linearClosed
values.comment: Draw a straigt line between the data points, connecting the ends.

values.name: monotoneX
values.comment: Draw a curve monotone in y assuming the points are monotone in x. Note, does not deal well with coincident points

values.name: monotoneY
values.comment: Draw a curve monotone in y assuming the points are monotone in x.

values.name: natural
quadraticBezier
values.comment: Shorthand to draw a sequence of quadratic bezier segments
values.type: Vector2.Vec2 Float -> List ( Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float ) -> SubPath.SubPath

values.name: radial
values.comment: Interpret a 2D vector as a `(angle, radius)` pair. The angle is in radians. The first argument is the center.

values.name: repeatFinalPoint
values.comment:
Repeat the final element of a list

Similar to `repeatFirstPoint`, this can be used to make some curves hit their final control point.

values.name: repeatFirstPoint
values.comment:
Repeat the first element of a list

This is sometimes useful for curves that don't go through their first control point (catmullRom, cardinal). Repeating the first point
makes the curve actually hit the first control point.

values.name: smoothCubicBezier
values.comment: Shorthand to draw a sequence of smooth cubic bezier segments
values.type: Vector2.Vec2 Float -> ( Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float ) -> List ( Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float ) -> SubPath.SubPath

values.name: smoothQuadraticBezier
values.comment: Shorthand to draw a sequence of smooth quadratic bezier segments
values.type: Vector2.Vec2 Float -> ( Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float ) -> List (Vector2.Vec2 Float) -> SubPath.SubPath

values.name: step
values.comment: Step goes some distance to the right, then to the y-coordinate of the next data point, and then draws to the next point. The first argument determines where the step is. - `step 1 points` is `stepAfter` - `step 0 points` is `stepBefore` - `step 0.5 points` steps exactly in the middle

values.name: stepAfter
stepBefore
toPolarWithCenter
values.comment:
Convert `(angle, radius)` pairs to `(x, y)` coordinates, relative to the given vector.

This function is used by radial and can be used to use radial with different interpolations, for instance.

    radialNatural : Vec2 Float -> List (Vec2 Float) -> SubPath
    radialNatural ( x, y ) =
        natural << toPolarWithCenter ( x, y )
values.type: Vector2.Vec2 Float -> List (Vector2.Vec2 Float) -> List (Vector2.Vec2 Float)

name: SubPath
comment: ## Types @docs SubPath ## Construction @docs subpath, empty ## Conversion @docs element, toString, toSegments, fromSegments, unwrap ## Composition import Curve curve : SubPath curve = Curve.quadraticBezier ( 0, 0 ) [ ( ( 0.5, -0.5 ), ( 1.0, 0 ) ) ] down : SubPath down = Curve.linear [ ( 0, 0 ), ( 0, 1 ) ] curve |> connect down |> SubPath.toString --> "M0,0 Q0.5,-0.5 1,0 L0,0 L0,1" curve |> continue down |> SubPath.toString --> "M0,0 Q0.5,-0.5 1,0 L1,1" curve |> continueSmooth down |> SubPath.toString --> "M0,0 Q0.5,-0.5 1,0 L1.707106781187,0.707106781187" close curve |> SubPath.toString --> "M0,0 Q0.5,-0.5 1,0 Z" @docs continue , connect, continueSmooth, close ## Mapping @docs reverse, compress @docs translate, rotate, scale @docs mapCoordinate, mapWithCursorState ## Conversion @docs fromLowLevel, toLowLevel

types.name: SubPath
types.comment:
Type representing a subpath

A subpath is one moveto command followed by an arbitrary number of drawto commands.

values.name: close
values.comment: Append a ClosePath at the end of the subpath (if none is present)

values.name: compress
values.comment:
Try to merge adjacent instructions

This conversion is costly (timewise), but can shorten a subpath
considerably, meaning other functions are faster.

Additionally, the toString output can become shorter.

values.name: connect
values.comment: Join two subpaths, connecting them with a straight line

values.name: continue
values.comment: Start the second subpath where the first one ends

values.name: continueSmooth
values.comment: Start the second subpath where the first one ends, and rotate it to continue smoothly

values.name: element
values.comment:
Construct an svg path element from a `Path` with the given attributes

    Svg.svg []
        [ SubPath.element mySubPath [ stroke "black" ] ]

values.name: empty
values.comment: An empty subpath

values.name: fromLowLevel
values.comment:
Converting a svg-path-lowlevel subpath into a one-true-path subpath. Used in parsing

> Beware that the moveto is always interpreted as **Absolute**.

values.name: fromSegments
values.comment:
Convert a list of segments to a path

In the conversion, the starting point of a segment is discarded:
It is assumed that for every two adjacent segments in the list, the first segment's end point is the second segment's starting point

    import Segment exposing (line)
    import LowLevel.Command exposing (moveTo, lineTo)


    [ line (0,0) (10,10) , line (10, 10) (20, 10) ]
        |> fromSegments
        --> subpath (moveTo (0,0)) [ lineTo [ (10, 10)], lineTo [ (20, 10) ] ]

values.name: mapCoordinate
values.comment: Map over all the 2D coordinates in a subpath

values.name: mapWithCursorState
values.comment:
Map over each drawto with the CursorState available.

The CursorState contains the subpath start position and the current cursor position at the
current DrawTo

values.name: reverse
values.comment:
Reverse a subpath

The direction of a subpath [can be important][reverse] if you want to use SVG fills.

    mySubPath : SubPath
    mySubPath =
        subpath (moveTo (0,0))
            [ lineTo [ (10, 10)], lineTo [ (20, 10) ] ]

    mySubPath
        |> reverse
        |> reverse
        --> mySubPath



[reverse]: https://pomax.github.io/svg-path-reverse/

values.name: rotate
values.comment: Rotate a subpath around its starting point by an angle (in radians).

values.name: scale
values.comment:
Scale the subpath in the x and y direction

For more complex scaling operations, define a transformation matrix and use `mapCoordinate`.

values.name: subpath
values.comment:
Construct a subpath

    subpath (moveTo (0,0)) [ lineTo [ (10,10), (10, 20) ] ]

values.name: toLowLevel
values.comment: Converting a one-true-path subpath into a svg-path-lowlevel subpath. Used in toString

values.name: toSegments
values.comment:
Convert a subpath to its `Segment`s

    subpath (moveTo (0,0)) [ lineTo [ (10, 10), (20, 10) ] ]
        |> toSegments
        --> [ line (0,0) (10,10) , line (10, 10) (20, 10) ]

values.name: toString
values.comment:
Convert a subpath into SVG path notation

    import LowLevel.Command exposing (moveTo, lineTo)

    line : SubPath
    line = subpath (moveTo (0,0)) [ lineTo [ (10,10), (10, 20) ] ]

    SubPath.toString line --> "M0,0 L10,10 10,20"

values.name: translate
values.comment: Translate the subpath by a vector

values.name: unwrap
values.comment: deconstruct a subpath into its components
values.type: SubPath.SubPath -> Maybe.Maybe { moveto : LowLevel.Command.MoveTo , drawtos : List LowLevel.Command.DrawTo }

name: Segment
comment:
An alternative view on paths that is convenient for mathematical operations.

When we look at a path as a list of elemental `Segment`s, it becomes easier to reason about it.
The segment data type has four segment types:

* `line` straigt line segment
* `quadratic` a quadratic bezier curve segment
* `cubic` a cubic bezier curve segment
* `arc` an elliptical arc segment

All four of these are mathematically well-defined, and there is a wide range of
operations that we can perform on them:

* `length` the arc length of a segment
* `angle` between two segments
* `derivative` or curvature
* `reverse` reverse a segment - this can be used to [let the browser fill your svg correctly][reverse]

These operations are backed by the great [OpenSolid][] package, and in turn back many of the operations
in `SubPath`.

[reverse]: https://pomax.github.io/svg-path-reverse/
[OpenSolid]: http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/opensolid/geometry/latest

@docs Segment
@docs line, quadratic, cubic, arc

# Operations

@docs at, angle
@docs derivativeAt, derivativeAtFirst, derivativeAtFinal
@docs firstPoint, finalPoint, reverse


# Conversion

@docs toDrawTo, toSegment, toCursorState

values.name: angle
values.comment:
The signed angle (in radians) between the end of segment1 and the start of segment2

    a : Segment
    a = line ( 0, 0 ) ( 1, 0 )

    b : Segment
    b = line ( 0, 0 ) ( 0, 1 )

    angle a b --> degrees 90

    angle b a --> degrees -90

values.name: arc
values.comment: Make an elliptic arc segment

values.name: at
values.comment:
Get the location at a point on the curve, only defined in the range [0, 1].


    at 0.5 (line (0,0) (10, 0)) --> ( 5, 0 )

    at 0.5 (quadratic (0,0) (5, 10) (10, 0)) --> ( 5, 5 )

values.name: cubic
values.comment: Make a cubic bezier segment
values.type: ( Float, Float ) -> ( Float, Float ) -> ( Float, Float ) -> ( Float, Float ) -> Segment.Segment

values.name: derivativeAt
values.comment:
Get the derivative at a point on the curve, only defined in the range [0, 1].

    import LowLevel.Command exposing
        ( EllipticalArcArgument
        , largestArc
        , clockwise
        )

    derivativeAt 0.5 (line (0,0) (1,1))
        --> (0.7071067811865475,0.7071067811865475)

    argument : EllipticalArcArgument
    argument =
        { target = ( 10, 0 )
        , radii = ( 5, 5 )
        , xAxisRotate = 0
        , arcFlag = largestArc
        , direction = clockwise
        }

    derivativeAt 0.5 (arc (0,0)  argument) --> ( 1, 0)

values.name: derivativeAtFinal
values.comment: The derivative at the ending point of the segment

values.name: derivativeAtFirst
values.comment: The derivative at the starting point of the segment

values.name: finalPoint
values.comment: Extract the final point from a segment

values.name: firstPoint
values.comment: Extract the first point from a segment

values.name: line
values.comment: Make a line segment

values.name: quadratic
values.comment: Make a quadratic bezier segment
values.type: ( Float, Float ) -> ( Float, Float ) -> ( Float, Float ) -> Segment.Segment

values.name: reverse
values.comment: Reverse a line segment

values.name: toCursorState
toDrawTo
values.comment: Convert a segment to a drawto instruction. forgets the starting point.

values.name: toSegment
values.comment:
Convert a drawto into a segment

This function needs the previous segment to the starting point and (for bezier curves) the control points

    import LowLevel.Command exposing (DrawTo(EllipticalArc), CursorState)

    start : CursorState
    start = { start = (0,0), cursor = (0,0), previousControlPoint = Nothing }

    drawto : DrawTo
    drawto =
            EllipticalArc
                [ { target = (10, 0)
                  , radii = (5,5)
                  , xAxisRotate = 90
                  , arcFlag = largestArc
                  , direction = clockwise
                  }
                ]

    expected : List Segment
    expected =
         [ Arc
            { start = (0,0)
            , end = (10, 0)
            , radii = (5,5)
            , xAxisRotate = pi / 2
            , arcFlag = largestArc
            , direction = clockwise
            }
          ]

    toSegment start drawto --> expected

name: LowLevel.Command

aliases.name: CursorState
aliases.comment:
* `start` start of the subpath (most recent `MoveTo`)
* `cursor` the current cursor position
* `previousControlPoint` if the previous drawto instruction was a curveTo (cubic or quadratic), then
    this value stores Just its last control point position, else Nothing
aliases.type: { start : Vector2.Vec2 Float , cursor : Vector2.Vec2 Float , previousControlPoint : Maybe.Maybe ( Float, Float ) }

aliases.name: EllipticalArcArgument
aliases.comment:
The arguments for an Arc

    argument : EllipticalArcArgument
    argument =
        { start = ( 0, 42 )
        , end = ( 42, 0 )
        , radii = ( 1, 1 )
        , xAxisRotate = 90
        , arcFlag = largestArc
        , direction = clockwise
        }

The xAxisRotate parameter is in degrees (note that in the `Segment` module, it is in radians).
aliases.type: { radii : ( Float, Float ) , xAxisRotate : Float , arcFlag : Path.LowLevel.ArcFlag , direction : Path.LowLevel.Direction , target : Vector2.Vec2 Float }

types.name: DrawTo
types.comment:
Constructors for DrawTo instructions

You may miss some constructs in comparison to SVG. Only absolute coordinates are
supported, and the smooth curve variants are removed. These choices were
made to keep the number of constructors small.

Relative coordinates can always
be transformed to abslute ones, and smooth (also known as short-hand) curve extensions
can be achieved with `Curve.smoothQuadraticBezier` and `Curve.smoothCubicBezier`.
cases: List ( Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float )

values.name: arcTo
values.comment: An elliptical arc. The `A` instruction.

values.name: clockwise
values.comment: Corresponds to a sweep flag of 0

values.name: closePath
values.comment: Draw a straight line from the cursor position to the starting position of the path. The `Z` instruction.

values.name: counterClockwise
values.comment: Corresponds to a sweep flag of 1

values.name: cubicCurveTo
values.comment: A cubic bezier. The `C` instruction.
values.type: List ( Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float ) -> LowLevel.Command.DrawTo

values.name: fromLowLevelDrawTos
values.type: List Path.LowLevel.DrawTo -> LowLevel.Command.CursorState -> ( LowLevel.Command.CursorState, List LowLevel.Command.DrawTo )

values.name: horizontalTo
values.comment: Specific version of `lineTo` that only moves horizontally. The `H` instruction.

values.name: largestArc
values.comment:
Corresponds to an arc flag of 1
thDefault

values.name: lineTo
values.comment: Draw a series of line segments to absolute positions. The `L` instruction.

values.name: mapCoordinateDrawTo
values.comment: Transform the coordinates in a drawto

values.name: merge
values.comment:
Merge adjacent commands if possible

    merge (lineTo [ (0,0) ]) (lineTo [ (10, 10) ]) --> Ok (lineTo [ (0,0) , (10, 10) ])

    merge (lineTo [ (0,0) ]) closePath --> Err (lineTo [ (0,0) ], closePath)
values.type: LowLevel.Command.DrawTo -> LowLevel.Command.DrawTo -> Result.Result ( LowLevel.Command.DrawTo, LowLevel.Command.DrawTo ) LowLevel.Command.DrawTo

values.name: moveTo
values.comment: Move to a position on the canvas without drawing.

values.name: quadraticCurveTo
values.comment: A quadratic bezier. The `Q` instruction.
values.type: List ( Vector2.Vec2 Float, Vector2.Vec2 Float ) -> LowLevel.Command.DrawTo

values.name: smallestArc
values.comment: Corresponds to an arc flag of 0

values.name: toLowLevelDrawTo
values.comment: Convert a one-true-path drawto to a svg-path-lowlevel drawto. Used in conversion to string

values.name: toLowLevelMoveTo
values.comment: Convert a one-true-path moveto to a svg-path-lowlevel moveto. Used in conversion to string

values.name: updateCursorState
values.comment:
Simulate the effect of a drawto command on the cursor position


    state : CursorState
    state =
        { start = (0,0)
        , cursor = (10, 10)
        , previousControlPoint = Nothing
        }

    updateCursorState (lineTo [(20, 10)]) state
        --> { start = (0,0), cursor = (20,10), previousControlPoint = Nothing }

    updateCursorState (quadraticCurveTo [(( 15, 20), (20, 10))]) state
        --> { start = (0,0), cursor = (20,10), previousControlPoint = Just (15, 20) }

values.name: verticalTo
values.comment: Specific version of `lineTo` that only moves vertically. The `V` instruction
